question: Question_10_(a)
statement:
Find the number \emph{a} which make the matrix below diagonalizable. (No
need to diagonalize them.)

$\begin{bmatrix}
0 &1 &2 \\ 
0 &3 &a \\ 
0 &0 &0 
\end{bmatrix}$
sols:
For an \emph{n} by \emph{n} matrix to be diagonalizable, the matrix must
have n distinct eigenvectors. First let$^{\prime}$s find the eigenvalues
of a

$\text{det}(\begin{bmatrix}
0-\lambda &1 &2 \\ 
0 &3-\lambda &a \\ 
0 &0 &0-\lambda 
\end{bmatrix})=\lambda^{2}(3-\lambda)=0$Solve the equation above to get
$\displaystyle \lambda _{1}=3,\lambda _{2}=\lambda_{3}=0$We got a double root here, so we need to have 2 corresponding
eigenvectors for $\lambda=0$. When

$\displaystyle \lambda=0,A-\lambda I= \begin{bmatrix}
0 &1 &2 \\ 
0 &3 &a \\ 
0 &0 &0 
\end{bmatrix}$In order to have 2 eigenvectors, we need to have 2 free variables here
i.e. we need to have $\frac{1}{3}=\frac{2}{a}$ Solve this to get $a=6$.
